herbs.name: Chamomile
herbs.description: Chamomile is one of the most ancient medicinal herbs known to mankind. This gentle, daisy-like flower has been used for thousands of years to calm nerves, soothe digestive issues, and promote restful sleep.

preparations.tea: 1-2 tsp dried flowers per cup, steep 5-10 minutes
preparations.bath: Add 1 cup dried flowers to bath water

herbs.dosage: Tea: 1-4 cups daily. Tincture: 2-4 ml, 3 times daily
contraindications: Allergy to plants in the daisy family
herbs.harvestingTips: Harvest flowers when fully open on a dry morning after dew has evaporated

herbs.name: Lavender
herbs.description: Lavender is beloved for its distinctive fragrance and beautiful purple flowers. Native to the Mediterranean, it has been used for over 2,500 years for its calming properties and antiseptic qualities.

preparations.tea: 1 tsp dried flowers per cup, steep 5-10 minutes
preparations.essential oil: 2-4 drops in carrier oil for massage
preparations.bath: Add 1/2 cup dried flowers or 5-10 drops oil to bath
preparations.pillow: Place dried flowers in pillowcase for better sleep

herbs.dosage: Tea: 1-3 cups daily. Essential oil: Use diluted only
contraindications: Can cause skin irritation in sensitive individuals
herbs.harvestingTips: Cut stems just as flowers begin to open for highest oil content

herbs.name: Peppermint
herbs.description: Peppermint is a hybrid mint, a cross between watermint and spearmint. Known for its cooling sensation and fresh taste, it's one of the most popular herbs for digestive health.

preparations.tea: 1-2 tsp dried leaves per cup, steep 5-10 minutes
preparations.essential oil: 1-2 drops in water for digestive issues
preparations.steam inhalation: 3-4 drops in hot water, inhale vapors

herbs.dosage: Tea: 1-3 cups daily, especially after meals
contraindications: May worsen acid reflux in some people
Avoid essential oil in children under 6
herbs.harvestingTips: Harvest just before flowering for best flavor and potency

herbs.name: Ginger
herbs.description: Ginger is a flowering plant whose rhizome is widely used as a spice and folk medicine. Native to Southeast Asia, it has been used for over 5,000 years for both culinary and medicinal purposes.

preparations.tea: 1-2 tsp fresh grated root per cup, steep 10 minutes
preparations.compress: Apply grated ginger for joint pain

herbs.harvestingTips: Harvest after 8-10 months when leaves yellow and die back

herbs.name: Echinacea
herbs.description: Echinacea is a group of flowering plants native to North America. Used traditionally by Native Americans, it's now one of the most popular herbs for immune system support.

preparations.tea: 1-2 tsp dried root or leaves per cup, steep 10-15 minutes
preparations.tincture: 2-4 ml, 3 times daily at onset of illness
preparations.topical: Apply tea or diluted tincture to wounds

herbs.dosage: Use for 7-10 days at onset of illness, then take a break
herbs.harvestingTips: Harvest roots in fall after 3-4 years of growth

herbs.name: Turmeric
herbs.description: Turmeric is a rhizomatous herbaceous perennial plant native to Southeast Asia. Its bright yellow color and powerful anti-inflammatory properties have made it a staple in both cuisine and traditional medicine.

preparations.golden milk: 1/2 tsp powder in warm milk with black pepper
preparations.paste: Mix with honey for topical use

herbs.dosage: 500-2000mg daily, always with black pepper for absorption
contraindications: High doses may cause stomach upset
herbs.harvestingTips: Harvest rhizomes after 8-10 months when leaves start to dry

herbs.name: Valerian
herbs.description: Valerian is a perennial flowering plant native to Europe and Asia. Its root has been used since ancient Greek and Roman times as a remedy for insomnia and nervous tension.

preparations.tea: 1-2 tsp dried root per cup, steep 10-15 minutes
preparations.bath: Add strong tea to bath water

herbs.harvestingTips: Harvest roots in fall of second or third year

herbs.name: Elderberry
herbs.description: Elderberry is a deciduous shrub native to Europe, known for its dark purple berries rich in antioxidants. Both flowers and berries have been used medicinally for centuries.

preparations.tea: 1-2 tsp dried berries or flowers per cup

herbs.dosage: Syrup: 1 tbsp 2-3 times daily during illness
herbs.harvestingTips: Harvest berries when fully ripe and dark purple

herbs.name: Calendula
herbs.description: Calendula is a bright orange flowering plant native to the Mediterranean. It has been used since ancient times for its remarkable skin-healing properties.

preparations.oil: Infuse flowers in carrier oil for 2-4 weeks
preparations.compress: Apply cooled tea to affected area

herbs.dosage: External use as needed. Tea: 1-3 cups daily
contraindications: May cause allergic reactions in sensitive individuals
herbs.harvestingTips: Pick flowers regularly to encourage more blooms

herbs.name: Lemon Balm
herbs.description: Lemon balm is a perennial herb from the mint family, native to southern Europe. Its lemony scent and calming properties have made it a favorite for centuries.

preparations.tea: 2-3 tsp fresh leaves or 1 tsp dried per cup
preparations.essential oil: Dilute for topical use on cold sores
preparations.bath: Add tea to bath for relaxation

herbs.dosage: Tea: 1-3 cups daily. Fresh leaves can be eaten freely

growingInfo.water: Regular watering, don't let dry out

herbs.harvestingTips: Harvest before flowering for best flavor
